verse: When Joab, the son of David’s sister Zeruiah, realized that David was preoccupied with Absalom, he took matters into his own hands.
He brought a wise woman from Tekoa and instructed her.
When this woman from Tekoa came before the king, she fell on her face, prostrate before him, and showed the appropriate respect due the king.
Then the woman asked for liberty to speak freely, and David agreed.
Joab lay facedown on the ground before the king and honored him.
Joab traveled to Geshur, found Absalom, and brought him home to Jerusalem. But David would not see him.
Now there was no one in Israel more handsome than Absalom; from the soles of his feet to the top of his head, he was flawless.
When he cut his long hair (which he did once a year, as he needed it), his hair weighed five pounds, according to the king’s measuring system.
Absalom was the father of three sons and a beautiful daughter he named Tamar, after his sister.
Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two years without seeing his father David, the king,
and at last Absalom sent a message to Joab that he wanted to be brought before David. But Joab did not answer his summons. Absalom sent him a second message, and again Joab did not come.
So Absalom gathered his servants and gave them orders.
Joab got up and confronted Absalom at his house.

So Joab brought David this message, and David sent for Absalom, who came before his father the king and lay facedown on the ground in honor of him. David kissed Absalom and welcomed him back into his good graces.
